case_name: Matru alias Girish Chandra v. State

facts.text: Appeal filed in Supreme Court as Criminal Appeal No. 165 of 1968 by special leave

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 165 of 1968. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated February 8 1968 of the Allahabad High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 2305 of 1965.

facts.text: Allahabad High Court delivered judgment and order dated February 8, 1968 in Criminal Appeal No. 2305 of 1965

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated February 8 1968 of the Allahabad High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 2305 of 1965. S. R. Chari J. P. Goyal and G. S. Chatterjee, for the appellant.

facts.text: Appellant Matru alias Girish Chandra convicted under S. 302 read with S. 34 IPC and sentenced to life imprisonment

anchor.surface_text: In this appeal by special leave the appellant Matru alias Girish Chandra challenges his conviction under S. 302 read with s. 34, I.P.C. and under S. 382, I.P.C. For the former offence he was sentenced to imprisonment for life

facts.text: Appellant convicted under S. 382 IPC and sentenced to 4 years rigorous imprisonment, to run concurrently

anchor.surface_text: and under S. 382, I.P.C. For the former offence he was sentenced to imprisonment for life and for the latter to rigorous imprisonment for four years. Both the sentences were directed to run concurrently.

facts.text: Offences alleged committed on May 29, 1964 between 10 and 11 a.m. in Shamsabad township

anchor.surface_text: The offences were alleged to have been committed on May 29, 1964 between 10 and II a.m. in the township of Shamsabad. The appellant and the deceased were admittedly next door neighbors in Mohalla Chaukhanda at the relevant-time.

facts.text: Murder of Smt. Omwati, wife of Ram Chander PW1, and their three-year-old son Sua Lal

anchor.surface_text: committed to the Court of Sessions for trial for offences under ss. 302/34, I.P.C. for the murder of Smt. Omwati, wife of Ram Chander  P.W. 1  and of their three years old son Sua Lal

facts.text: Theft of cash, ornaments and other things from house of deceased under S. 382 IPC

anchor.surface_text: and under s. 382, I.P.C. for committing theft of cash, armaments and other things from the house of the deceased.

facts.text: Appellant Matru and deceased Omwati were next door neighbors in Mohalla Chaukhanda

anchor.surface_text: The appellant and the deceased were admittedly next door neighbors in Mohalla Chaukhanda at the relevant-time. Rain Chandra had two sons, the elder one Ramji being six years old.

facts.text: Ram Chandra left house at about 9 a.m. on May 29, 1964 for his shop, leaving wife and two sons

anchor.surface_text: On the day of occurrence at about 9 a.m. Ram Chandra left his house for his shop about three, furlongs away, leaving behind in the house his wife and two sons.

facts.text: Omwati sent elder son Ramji to shop with food about an hour later

anchor.surface_text: About an hour later Omwati sent the elder son to the shop with some food for his father. A few minutes later Ram Chandra sent to his house some vegetables through his servant.

facts.text: Servant informed Ram Chandra that wife lying in pool of blood; Ram Chandra found wife dead in courtyard near well, son Sua Lal dead in room, box opened, contents pilfered, ornaments missing

anchor.surface_text: After sometime his servant returned to the shop and informed Ram Chandra that his wife was lying in the house in pool of blood. After calling his nephew to look after the shop Ram Chandra immediately went to his house and found his wife lying dead in the courtyard near the well whereas his 3 year old son Sua Lal was lying dead in a room close to the courtyard. The box inside the room also appeared to have been opened and its contents pilfered.

facts.text: FIR lodged at police station Shamsabad at 12:40 p.m. on May 29, 1964, no suspect named, Rs.200 cash and three ornaments including ring stolen

anchor.surface_text: Information of the occurrence was lodged at the police station Shamsabad at about 12.40 in the afternoon. But as he did not suspect anyone he merely stated the circumstances in which he came to know of the occurrence and found his wife and child dead in the house. It was stated in the report that Rs. 200/- in cash and three ornaments including a ring had been taken away by the miscreants.

facts.text: Matru present at Ram Chandra's house before FIR lodged and remained till report made to police

anchor.surface_text: Matru, appellant, who was the next door neighbour came to Ram Chandras house before the first information report was lodged and remained with him till the report was made to the police.

facts.text: Chhotey Lal PW2 saw Matru and two unknown persons entering Ram Chandra's house at 10-10:30 a.m. on May 29, 1964

anchor.surface_text: Next morning it appears Chhotey Lal W. 2  and Nathu Lal  P.W. 10  went to see Ram Chandra between 6, and 7 a.m. Chhotey Lal informed him that he  Chhotey Lal  had seen Matra and two unknown persons entering Ram Chandras house at about 10 or 10.30 a.m. on the previous day

facts.text: Nathu Lal PW10 saw Matru and two others coming out of Ram Chandra's house at about 11 a.m. on May 29, 1964

anchor.surface_text: and Nathu Lal gave him the information that at about 11 a.m. on the day of the occurrence he had seen Matru and. two other persons coming out of his house.

facts.text: Strained relations between Omwati and Matru's wife about six months prior to occurrence; quarrel where Matru's wife threw stone hitting Omwati

anchor.surface_text: It is said that about six months prior to the occurrence relations between Omwati and the wife-of Matru, appellant, had become strained. ... About six months prior to, the occurrence an incident is stated to have taken place which gave rise to a quarrel between the two women. Matrus wife threw a stone which struck Omwati on her head.

facts.text: Matru disappeared after inquest on May 29, 1964

anchor.surface_text: After the occurrence, the appellant, it appears, remained in his house till the inquest was over but thereafter he seems to have disappeared.

facts.text: Matru apprehended on June 1, 1964; spectacle case containing spectacles and gold ring recovered from his dhoti

anchor.surface_text: On June 1, when the investigating officer learnt that Matru was likely to go to his village to see his children he was apprehended and on search of his person a spectacle case containing a pair of spectacles and a gold ring was recovered from the folds of his dhoti.

facts.text: Mohar Singh arrested on September 13, 1964; shawl recovered from Darbarilal PW17 at his instance

anchor.surface_text: But Mohar Singh could not be arrested till September 13, 1964. When arrested, he offered to recover a shawl, one of ,the stolen properties, which he had sold to Darbarilal  P.W. 17  for Rs. 70/-. The shawl was accordingly recovered at Mohar Singhs instance from Darbarilal.

facts.text: Sessions Judge convicted Matru under 302/34 and 382 IPC, sentenced life and 4 years RI; acquitted Mohar Singh and Saheb Singh

anchor.surface_text: The Sessions Judge found the appellant guilty of murder and also of an offence under S. 382, I.P.C. ... Mohar Singh was, acquitted of the offence under S. 302/ 34, I.P.C. as also of the offence under S. 382, I.P.C. ... Saheb Singh was given benefit of doubt and acquitted.

facts.text: Allahabad High Court upheld Matru's conviction, acquitted Mohar Singh

anchor.surface_text: Both the convicts appealed to the High Court. That Court came to the conclusion that Matru had a motive to commit the crime ... Mohar Singh, from whose possession nothing had been recovered was given benefit of doubt and acquitted.

facts.text: Supreme Court acquitted appellant Matru

anchor.surface_text: We are, therefore, constrained to allow this appeal, set aside the appellants conviction and acquit him.

facts.text: Ring recovered from Matru identified as one worn by deceased

anchor.surface_text: The ring, which had been recovered from Matrus possession at the time of his arrest was held to be the one which the deceased was wearing when her husband left the house in the morning of the occurrence.

facts.text: Matru absconded after FIR lodged

anchor.surface_text: All these circumstances taken along with the fact that Matru had absconded were held to connect the appellant with the crime beyond reasonable doubt.
under S. 302 read with s. 34, I.P.C. and under S. 382, I.P.C. For the former offence he was sentenced to imprisonment for life
s. 34, I.P.C. For the former offence he was sentenced to imprisonment for life and for the latter to rigorous imprisonment for four years.

anchor.surface_text: In this Court it was strongly argued on behalf of the appel- lant Matru that the circumstantial evidence does number establish his companyplicity in the offence charged. The Police investigation was also assailed and it was submitted that identification of the articles alleged to have been stolen and later recovered was number of much value because the articles alleged to have been recovered were companymonly available

issues.text: Whether this Court should scrutinise and appraise the evidence itself in a criminal appeal under Article 136 of the Constitution?

anchor.surface_text: Normally this Court doe number go into the evidence and appraise it for itself in criminal appeals under Art. 136 of the Constitution because this Article does number confer a right of appeal on a party. It merely clothes this Court with discretionary power to scrutinise and go into the evidence in special circumstances

issues.text: Whether the stolen articles were validly recovered from the appellant's possession?

anchor.surface_text: This takes us to the recovery of the alleged stolen articles from the appellant and their identification. The main evidence of recovery companysists of the statements of Head Constable- Ahibaran Singh  P.W. 5  and of Nathu  P.W. 10  and the recovery memo Ex. Ka-1 dated June 1, 1964.

anchor.surface_text: Having number been impressed by the evidence of recovery, the identification test of the articles can be of little help to the prosecution, though even on that point the prosecution evidence is equally uninspiring. holdings.text: The circumstantial evidence does not establish the appellant's guilt beyond reasonable doubt; conviction set aside and appellant acquitted.

anchor.surface_text: the cumulative effect of the circumstantial evidence in this case falls far short of the test required for sustaining conviction. We are, therefore, constrained to allow this appeal, set aside the appellants conviction and acquit him.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Chain of circumstances incomplete, unreliable recovery and identification, weak motive, absconding not conclusive, no weapon or blood stains; fails standard from Hanumant case.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Discretionary jurisdiction exercised where circumstantial evidence case, co-accused acquitted, neighbour involved, to prevent substantial injustice.

holdings.text: Recovery of stolen articles from appellant not proved reliably; evidence unsafe to rely upon.

anchor.surface_text: This takes us to the recovery of the alleged stolen articles from the appellant and their identification. The main evidence of recovery consists of the statements of Head Constable- Ahibaran Singh P.W. 5 and of Nathu P.W. 10 and the recovery memo Ex. Ka-1 dated June 1, 1964.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Testimony of PW5 and PW10 unreliable; anonymous approver not produced; improbable collection of witnesses in short time; no corroboration.

holdings.text: Test identification proceedings of recovered articles unreliable and unworthy of reliance.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Tests not substantive evidence; delayed (June to Oct); improper handling, shown to contractor; dissimilar articles mixed; magistrate's testimony unsatisfactory.

precedents.citation: Prabhu Babaji Navle v. State of Bombay.  1

anchor.surface_text: ary to law. For this submission-he relied on Prabhu Babaji Navle v. State of Bombay.  1  Finally counsel argued on the authority of Hanumant v. State of M.P.  2  that in case of circumstantial evidence the circumstances from which the conclusion of guilt is to be drawn should be fully established and all the established facts should be consistent only with the hypothesis of the guilt of the accused. In the present case the circumstantial evidence is not of conclusive nature and tendency, said Shri Chari.
